abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Emergency Industrial
            Restart Project for Bosnia and Herzegovina were as follows:
            the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely,
            the institutional development impact was high, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that the agency was established by
            legislation and five new staff persons were employed to
            implement the project. A resident technical assistant was
            employed to assist the personnel in the agency in developing
            the knowledge and skills to implement the project. At the
            end of this process, the staff of the agency had acquired
            skills that were relevant to a more complex project of
            issuing guarantees that supported commercial risk. The
            Project Appraisal Document and the Development Credit
            Agreement proved that project funds could be used for a
            guarantee agency after the Closing Date. In retrospect, the
            agency should have been given the authority to use World
            Bank and donor funds to guarantee activities involving
            commercial risk as well as non commercial risk. If this
            broader mandate had been given at the outset, greater value
            would have been obtained from the technical assistance
            provided to support the guarantee program for non commercial
            risk, all available donor funds committed to the project
            would have been disbursed and the impact of the project in
            developing trade and generating growth would have been greater.
